{{Infobox scientist |image = |image_size = 150px | | name = Mandy Chessell | birth_date = ca 1965 | birth_place = [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]], England | residence = United Kingdom | citizenship = British | nationality = English | field = Computer Science, Software Engineering | work_institution = IBM | known_for = software inventions, innovation, model-driven software development tools, information management, design patterns | author_abbreviation_bot = | author_abbreviation_zoo = | prizes = Silver Medal Royal Academy of Engineering, BCS Karen Burt Prize, FREng, Female Inventor, Best Woman in Corporate Sector (2006 Blackberry Women and Technology Awards), Innovator of the Year (2012 Cisco Everywoman in Technology), Doctorate of Science (Plymouth University) | footnotes = BSc, MSc, FREng, CEng, FBCS, HonFIED, Distinguished Engineer, Master Inventor, Member of the IBM Academy of Technology, CBE }} '''Amanda Elizabeth Chessell''' {{Post-nominals|country=GBR|CBE|FREng|}} is a computer scientist and a Distinguished Engineer at IBM.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ingenia.org.uk/ingenia/articles.aspx?Index=559|title=Articles - '''Professor Mandy Chessell FREng'''|website=www.ingenia.org.uk}}</ref> She has been awarded the title of [[IBM Master Inventor]]. She is also a Member of the [[IBM Academy of Technology]].
Outside IBM, Chessell is the first woman to be awarded the Silver Medal of the [[Royal Academy of Engineering]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.raeng.org.uk/prizes/silver/winners_2000-2004.htm|title="RAEng Silver Medal"|website=raeng.org.uk}}</ref> In 2002 she was elected a Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering.<ref name=freng2002>{{cite web|url=http://www.raeng.org.uk/about/fellowship/fellowslist.htm?Page=13&Size=20|title="FREng2002"|website=raeng.org.uk}}</ref>
Chessell is a visiting professor<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sheffield.ac.uk/dcs/about/news/2009/chessellingenia09|title=Professor Mandy Chessell featured in Ingenia - 2009 - News - About the Department - Computer Science - The University of Sheffield|first=University of|last=Sheffield|website=www.sheffield.ac.uk}}</ref> at the [[University of Sheffield]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dcs.shef.ac.uk/cgi-bin/makeperson?A.Chessell|title=The University of Sheffield|website=www.dcs.shef.ac.uk}}</ref> and at the Surrey Centre for the Digital Economy (CoDE)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.SurreyCoDE.org|title=Home - Surrey CoDE|website=www.surreycode.org}}</ref> at the University of Surrey.
==Career at IBM==
Mandy Chessell joined IBM in 1987.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ingenia.org.uk/ingenia/articles.aspx?Index=559/|title=Articles - '''Professor Mandy Chessell FREng'''|website=www.ingenia.org.uk}}</ref> She is based at IBM's [[Hursley House|Hursley laboratory]] located near Winchester in Hampshire, UK.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-18687247 | title=Women and tech: Why don't girls want to be geeks? | accessdate=20 September 2013 | author=Wakefield, Jane | work=BBC News | date=3 August 2012}}</ref>
Her early work focused on distributed transaction processing, adding features to products such as [[CICS]], [[Encina (software)|Encina]], Component Broker and [[WebSphere Application Server]]. She has also work on event management, business process modelling and outside-in design (OID).
Then she focused on developing model-driven tools to simplify the analysis and design of large systems and then to automate their development. This work covers the development of user interfaces, services, information integration technology in the field of [[Master Data Management]].
Her work today is focused on data lake architectures, [[metadata management]] and [[information governance]].
Chessell frequently lectures on topics related to Computer Science and, in particular, innovation. Such lectures take place at universities such as Queen Mary University of London.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dcs.qmul.ac.uk/newsevents/detail.php?n=117|title=Queen Mary University of London|website=qmul.ac.uk}}</ref>
She was also one of the 30 women identified in the BCS Women in IT Campaign in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bcs.org/content/ConWebDoc/52511|title=Mandy Chessell |website=British Computer Society|publisher=British Computer Society|accessdate=13 April 2017}}</ref> Who were then featured in the e-book "Women in IT: Inspiring the next generation" produced by the BCS, The Chartered Institute for IT.<ref>{{cite book|title=Women in IT: Inspiring the next generation|date=1 Oct 2014|publisher=British Computer Society|isbn=978-1-78017-287-3|page=57|url=http://www.bcs.org/upload/pdf/women-it.pdf|accessdate=14 Oct 2014}}</ref>
==Achievements==
In 2000, she was among the first group of ''[[MIT Technology Review]]'' magazine's [[TR35|TR100]].
In 2001, she won the Royal Academy of Engineering Silver Medal for the invention and engineering of Reusable Software Component Architecture.<ref name=royalacad>{{cite web|url=http://www.raeng.org.uk/prizes/silver/winners_2000-2004.htm|title=Royal Academy of Engineering Silver Medal|website=raeng.org.uk}}</ref>
In 2002, she was elected a Fellow of The Royal Academy of Engineering.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.raeng.org.uk/about/fellowship/fellowslist.htm|title=The Fellowship – List of Fellows<!-- Bot generated title -->|website=raeng.org.uk}}</ref>
In 2004, Chessell won the British Computer Society nomination for the [http://www.wes.org.uk/content/karen-burt-memorial-award Women's Engineering Society "Karen Burt"] award.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bcs.org/server.php?show=nav.8187|title=BCS Nominees - Karen Burt Award - Awards and competitions - Events - BCS - The Chartered Institute for IT|website=www.bcs.org}}</ref>
In 2006, Chessell won a Female Inventor of the Year Award for building capacity for innovation.<ref>[http://www.bcs.org/server.php?show=ConWebDoc.3474 http://www.bcs.org/server.php?show=ConWebDoc.3474] ''Bcs.org''</ref>
Also in 2006, Chessell was awarded a prize for the Best Woman in the Corporate Sector at the Blackberry Women in Technology awards.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/technology/6111090.stm http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/technology/6111090.stm] ''News.bbc.co.uk''</ref>
In 2011, Chessell was made an honorary fellow of the [[Institution of Engineering Designers|Institution of Engineering Designers (IED)]].<ref>[http://www.ied.org.uk http://www.ied.org.uk] "IED"</ref>
In 2012, Chessell received Innovator of the Year at the [[Everywoman#everywoman Awards|Cisco everywoman in Technology Awards]].<ref>[http://www.everywoman.com/techawards/finalists http://www.everywoman.com/techawards/finalists] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120401143402/http://www.everywoman.com/techawards/finalists |date=1 April 2012 }} "Everywoman in Technology Award"</ref>
In 2013, Chessell received an Honorary Doctor of Science from [[Plymouth University]].<ref>[http://www1.plymouth.ac.uk/graduation/honorarydegrees/honoraries2013/Pages/Amanda-Chessell.aspx http://www1.plymouth.ac.uk/graduation/honorarydegrees/honoraries2013/Pages/Amanda-Chessell.aspx] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019071056/http://www1.plymouth.ac.uk/graduation/honorarydegrees/honoraries2013/Pages/Amanda-Chessell.aspx |date=19 October 2013 }} "Honorary Doctorate of Science, Plymouth University"</ref>
In 2015, Chessell received an Honorary Doctorate of Technology from [[University of Brighton]].<ref>[https://www.brighton.ac.uk/about-us/news-and-events/news/2015/07-31-award-for-software-pioneer.aspx https://www.brighton.ac.uk/about-us/news-and-events/news/2015/07-31-award-for-software-pioneer.aspx] "Honorary Doctorate of Technology, University of Brighton"</ref>
She was appointed [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] (CBE) in the 2015 New Year Honours for services to engineering.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=61092|supp=y|page=N8|date=31 December 2014}}</ref><ref>[https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/391413/New_Year_Honours_List_2015.pdf 2015 New Year Honours List] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150102104907/https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/391413/New_Year_Honours_List_2015.pdf |date=2 January 2015 }}</ref>
In 2016, Chessell was named in the Top 50 Influential Women in Engineering List 2016<ref>[http://www.wes.org.uk/we50 http://www.wes.org.uk/we50] "WE50 - Top 50 Influential Women in Engineering List 2016"</ref> and received an Honorary Doctorate of Technology from [[University of South Wales]]<ref>http://www.southwales.ac.uk/about/graduation/honorary-awards-2016/professor-amanda-chessell-freng-ceng-fbcs-honfied "Honorary Doctorate of Technology, University of South Wales"</ref>
In 2017, Chessell received an Honorary Doctor of Science from [[University of Bath]].<ref>[http://www.bath.ac.uk/corporate-information/professor-amanda-elizabeth-chessell-cbe-freng-oration/ http://www.bath.ac.uk/corporate-information/professor-amanda-elizabeth-chessell-cbe-freng-oration/] "Professor Amanda Elizabeth Chessell CBE FREng: Oration"</ref>
==Education==
Chessell studied Computer Science from an early age and has both an [[O-Level]] and an [[A-Level]] in the subject. She studied at [[Plymouth Polytechnic]] up to 1987<ref>[http://www1.plymouth.ac.uk/graduation/honorarydegrees/honoraries2013/Pages/Amanda-Chessell.aspx Honorary Doctorates of Plymouth University] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019071056/http://www1.plymouth.ac.uk/graduation/honorarydegrees/honoraries2013/Pages/Amanda-Chessell.aspx |date=19 October 2013 }}</ref> and obtained a Bachelors Honours Degree in Computing with Informatics.<ref name="archive.bcs.org">[http://archive.bcs.org/BCS/Products/publishing/itnow/OnlineArchive/jan02/interview.htm http://archive.bcs.org/BCS/Products/publishing/itnow/OnlineArchive/jan02/interview.htm]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ''Archive.bcs.org''</ref>
Subsequently, Chessell joined [[IBM]] in 1987 at [https://web.archive.org/web/20081025101522/http://www-05.ibm.com/uk/locations/hursley_details.html Hursley Park], Winchester where she studied for a master's degree in software engineering at the [[University of Brighton]] (completed in 1997). Her studies at Brighton were sponsored by [[IBM]].<ref name="archive.bcs.org"/>

In a general meaning a nanoflake is a flake (that is, an uneven piece of material with one dimension substantially smaller than the other two) with at least one nanometric dimension (that is, between 1 and 100 nm). A flake is not necessarily perfectly flat but it is characterized by a plate-like form or structure. There are nanoflakes of all sorts of materials.
In a more restricted meaning, in the context of solar energy, '''Nano Flakes''' are a type of [[semiconductor]] that has potential for solar energy creation as the product itself is only in the prototype phase. With its [[Crystal structure|crystalline structure]] the crystals are able to absorb light and harvest 30 percent of solar energy directed at its surface. These Nano Flakes can potentially also help out with economic and environmental problems associated with solar energy. Working on this Nano Flake Technology is Dr. Martin Aagesen at the [[Niels Bohr Institute]] at the [[University of Copenhagen]] with a PhD from the Nano Science Center. When Dr. Martin Aagesen discovered and published this new idea in 2007 there was much publicity about it and sparked many people to work on it.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.renewableenergyworld.com/articles/2007/12/nano-flakes-could-make-pv-more-efficient-50956.html|title = Nano Flakes Could Make PV More Efficient|website = www.renewableenergyworld.com|access-date = 2016-02-02}}</ref> One major company that is working on these Nano structures is SunFlake which is a science company from the [[University of Copenhagen Nano-Science Center|Nano Science Center]] with Dr. Martin Aagesen as Chief Executive Officer (CEO). The funding for the Nano flakes came from Danish Venture Capital fund SEED capital and University of Copenhagen.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url = https://ec.europa.eu/environment/ecoap/about-eco-innovation/good-practices/denmark/16_en|title = Nano-flake structure boosts solar cell performance - Eco-innovation Action Plan - European Commission|website = Eco-innovation Action Plan|access-date = 2016-02-11}}</ref>
== Structure == The Nano flakes have a structure that contains tiny crystals in which millions of these crystals could fit into a single square centimeter. The tiny crystals absorb the sunlight and use the solar energy to convert it to electricity. This perfect crystalline structure is why this product can revolutionize solar energy.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url = http://www.gizmag.com/nano-technology-to-boost-solar-efficiency/8540/|title = Nano Flakes promise greater solar energy efficiency|website = www.gizmag.com|access-date = 2016-02-03}}</ref> The large surface to volume ratio and the texture of the surface of this nano structure provides a larger absorption rate of the sun's light energy. Also researchers are working on trying to combine it with different semiconducting materials since the usual requirements of a need for a similar crystal structure for the carrier substrate is less stressed in the Nano flakes structure. The carrier substrate in the Nano flakes purpose is to permit growth of the nano structures and works as a contact for the Nano structures when they are actively absorbing the sun's energy.<ref name=":3" />
== Purpose == Solar energy obtained from the Nano flakes can help benefit in a couple of ways. Nano flakes can potentially help lower the cost of solar energy. Also since more solar energy can theoretically be obtained from Nano flakes, their use can potentially keep the earth's environment cleaner by reducing the need for fossil fuels.
=== Cost === The high cost of solar energy stems from the difficulty of converting the solar energy into electricity for use, and less than 1 percent of the world's electricity comes from the sun because of this process.<ref name=":1" /> Nano flakes can potentially help with the economic issues of solar energy by lowering the cost due to an easier process and a better outcome of energy. Nano flake technology can potentially make it easier to convert solar energy into electricity estimated at twice the amount that today's [[solar cell]]s can harvest. This new technology can also potentially lower the cost of solar energy because it allows for a reduction in expensive semiconducting [[silicon]].<ref name=":0" /> Energy loss is also potentially reduced with a shorter distance of the solar energy transportation across smaller Nano flakes.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url = http://www.solarcity.com/residential/benefits-of-solar-energy|title = Uncover the Benefits of Solar Energy|website = solarcity.com|access-date = 2016-02-11}}</ref>
=== Environment === Nano Flake technology can also help keep the environment cleaner as the sun as the source it produces clean pure [[sustainable energy]] that can be converted into electricity.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url = https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2007/12/071218105420.htm|title = Nano Flakes May Revolutionize Solar Cells|website = www.sciencedaily.com|access-date = 2016-02-03}}</ref> While fossil fuel is the primary energy source for electricity, using solar energy obtained from Nano flakes will lower dependence on fossil fuels. When fossil fuels are burned for use they release a toxic gas which has a huge impact on earth's pollution.<ref name=":2" /> Also the process of obtaining these fossil fuels is not good for the environment, whether it be mining for coal, drilling for oil, or [[hydraulic fracturing]] of the earth's surface to reach the oil and gas.<ref>{{Cite journal|last = Boudet|first = Hilary|last2 = Clarke|first2 = Christopher|last3 = Bugden|first3 = Dylan|last4 = Maibach|first4 = Edward|last5 = Roser-Renouf|first5 = Connie|last6 = Leiserowitz|first6 = Anthony|date = 2014-02-01|title = "Fracking" controversy and communication: Using national survey data to understand public perceptions of hydraulic fracturing|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301421513010392|journal = Energy Policy|volume = 65|pages = 57–67|doi = 10.1016/j.enpol.2013.10.017}}</ref>

Network documentation is a form of [[technical documentation]]. It is the practice of maintaining records about [[Computer network|networks of computers]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://pluto.ksi.edu/~cyh/cis370/ebook/ch12b.htm|title=Lesson 1: Documenting a Running Network|last=|first=|date=|website=Knowledge Systems Institute|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161201150027/http://pluto.ksi.edu/~cyh/cis370/ebook/ch12b.htm|archive-date=1 December 2016|dead-url=yes|access-date=}}</ref> The documentation is used to give administrators information about how the network should look, perform and where to troubleshoot problems as they occur.
== Essential Parts of Network Documentation == As the purpose of network documentation is to keep networks running as smoothly as possible while minimizing downtime when repairs are necessary, essential parts of network documentation include:<ref name=":0" />
*Map of the entire network to include locations of hardware and the cabling that connects the hardware *Server information such as data on the individual servers, schedules and locations of backups *Software information such as current versions, dates, licensing and support *Vendor and contractor information *Service agreements *Detailed record of problems and solutions: dated along with procedures and results
Notation that helps administrators remember key details are the basics of network documentation while visual representations assist in helping administrators understand how equipment and the notation relates to one another.<ref>http://packetpushers.net/evolution-of-network-documentation/</ref>
<gallery> File:Sample-network-diagram.png|Example of a Basic [[Computer network diagram|Network Diagram]] </gallery> A basic network diagram includes hardware and shows how it is connected. Basic diagrams include L1/L2 drawing of the physical connectivity and layout of the network.<ref>http://packetpushers.net/network-documentation-best-practices-whats-important-how-to-track-it/</ref>
== Network Documentation Software == Though network documentation can be done by hand, for larger organizations network documentation software is utilized. Software applications can include diagrams, inventory management and circuit and cable traces. Examples include Graphical Networks' netTerrain<ref>http://graphicalnetworks.com/netterrain-logical-2/</ref>, [[Microsoft Visio]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://support.office.com/en-us/article/create-a-basic-network-diagram-f2020ce6-c20f-4342-84f7-bf4e7488843a|title=Create a basic network diagram - Visio|last=|first=|date=|website=Microsoft|publisher=|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180417083745/https://support.office.com/en-us/article/create-a-basic-network-diagram-f2020ce6-c20f-4342-84f7-bf4e7488843a?ocmsassetID=HA102748912&CorrelationId=cdbe611d-4331-43f1-90fe-ec3acd71a0f6&ui=en-US&rs=en-US&ad=US|archive-date=17 April 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=17 April 2018}}</ref>, Docusnap, [[Gliffy]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gliffy.com/examples/network-diagrams|title=UML Diagram Tool {{!}} How to Make UML Diagrams Online {{!}} Gliffy|last=|first=|date=|website=Gliffy|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180417101537/https://www.gliffy.com/examples/network-diagrams|archive-date=17 April 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=17 April 2018}}</ref>, Opnet's [[Netmapper]], and CENTREL Solutions' XIA Configuration<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.centrel-solutions.com/xiaconfiguration/|title=XIA Configuration Network Documentation Tool|accessdate=27 September 2017}}</ref> among others.

{{notability|date=January 2016}} {{Portal|Computer security|Cryptography}} '''Nitrokey''' is an open source [[USB]] key to enable secure encryption and signing of data. The secret keys are always stored inside the Nitrokey which protects against [[malware]] (such as [[computer viruses]]) and attackers. A user-chosen PIN and a tamper-proof smart card protect the Nitrokey in case of loss and theft.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Nitrokey {{!}} Secure your digital life|url = http://www.nitrokey.com|website = www.nitrokey.com|accessdate = 2016-01-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Introduction {{!}} Nitrokey|url = https://www.nitrokey.com/introduction|website = www.nitrokey.com|accessdate = 2016-01-07}}</ref>The hardware and software of Nitrokey are available as [[open source]], [[free software]] and [[open hardware]] which enables independent parties to verify the security of the device. Nitrokey is supported on [[Microsoft Windows]], [[Linux]], and [[macOS]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Krypto-Stick verschlüsselt Mails und Daten|url = https://www.heise.de/ct/ausgabe/2016-5-News-Sicherheit-3104236.html|website = c‘t Magazin für Computer und Technik.|accessdate = 2016-05-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Krypto-Multitool|url = https://www.heise.de/ct/ausgabe/2016-10-Krypto-Stick-NitroKey-Pro-3186997.html|website = c‘t Magazin für Computer und Technik.|accessdate = 2016-10-31}}</ref>
== History == In 2008 Jan Suhr, Rudolf Böddeker and another friend were travelling and found themselves looking to use encrypted emails in [[internet cafés]], which meant the secret keys had to remain secure against [[computer viruses]]. Some proprietary USB dongles existed at the time, but lacked in certain ways. Consequentially, they established as an [[open source]] project - Crypto Stick<ref>{{Cite web|title = Der mit Open-Source-Methoden entwickelte Crypto-USB-Stick|url = http://www.linux-magazin.de/Ausgaben/2010/12/Magisches-Leuchten|website = Linux-Magazin|accessdate = 2016-01-15}}</ref> - in August 2008 which grew to become Nitrokey.<ref>{{Cite web|title = GnuPG-SmartCard und den CryptoStick|url = https://www.privacy-handbuch.de/handbuch_32r.htm|website = Privacy-Handbuch|accessdate = 2016-01-15}}</ref> It was a spare-time project of the founders to develop a hardware solution to enable the secure usage of [[email encryption]]. The first version of the Crypto Stick was released on 27 December 2009. In late 2014 the founders decided to professionalize the project, which was renamed Nitrokey. Nitrokey's firmware was audited by German cybersecurity firm [[Cure53]] in May 2015,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Heiderich|first1=Mario|last2=Horn|first2=Jann|last3=Krein|first3=Nikolai|title=Pentest-Report Nitrokey Storage Firmware 05.2015|url=https://cure53.de/pentest-report_nitrokey.pdf|publisher=Cure53|accessdate=15 February 2016|date=May 2015}}</ref> and its hardware was audited by the same company in August 2015.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Nedospasov|first1=Dmitry|last2=Heiderich|first2=Mario|title=Pentest-Report Nitrokey Storage Hardware 08.2015|url=https://cure53.de/pentest-report_nitrokey-hardware.pdf|publisher=Cure53|accessdate=15 February 2016|date=August 2015}}</ref> The first four Nitrokey models became available on 18 September 2015.
== Technical features == Several Nitrokey models exist and the Nitrokey Pro is the flagship model. It contains the following features: * A secure key storage to support [[OpenPGP]] (popular with individuals) and [[S/MIME]] (popular with businesses) email encryption standards. Nitrokey can also be used with various 3rd party applications such as [[TrueCrypt]] and [[VeraCrypt]] for disk encryption. * [[One-time password]]s (which are similar to [[Transaction authentication number|TANs]] and used as a secondary security measure in addition to ordinary passwords). It supports the [[HMAC-based One-time Password Algorithm]] (HOTP, <nowiki>RFC 4226</nowiki>) and [[Time-based One-time Password Algorithm]] (TOTP, <nowiki>RFC 6238</nowiki>), which are compatible with [[Google Authenticator]]. * Client Certificate Authentication is used to administrate servers securely via SSH, access Virtual Private Networks via [[OpenVPN]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = How to secure your Linux environment with Nitrokey USB smart card|url = http://xmodulo.com/linux-security-with-nitrokey-usb-smart-card.html|website = Xmodulo|accessdate = 2016-01-15}}</ref> * Password Safe stores encrypted static passwords inside the Nitrokey.
The upcoming Nitrokey Storage provides the same features as the Nitrokey Pro and additionally contains an encrypted mass storage.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Nitrokey Storage: USB Security Key for Encryption|url = https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/nitrokey-storage-usb-security-key-for-encryption#/|website = Indiegogo|accessdate = 2016-01-15}}</ref>
== Characteristics == * Nitrokey's secret keys are stored securely internally. * A user-chosen PIN protects in case of loss and theft. * Nitrokey's tamper-proof design protects it from sophisticated physical attacks. * [[RSA (cryptosystem)|RSA]] keys of up to 4096 bit and [[Advanced Encryption Standard|AES-256]] are supported. * It is supported for [[Microsoft Windows]], [[macOS]] and [[Linux]]. * It is compatible with many popular software like [[Microsoft Outlook]], [[Mozilla Thunderbird]], and [[OpenSSH]]. * The secure implementation of the Nitrokey is published as open source and open hardware<ref>{{Cite web|title = Nitrokey|url = https://github.com/nitrokey|website = GitHub|accessdate = 2016-01-15}}</ref> to enable independent reviews of the [[source code]] and [[hardware layout]] and to ensure the absence of back doors and other security flaws.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Nitrokey Storage Firmware and Hardware Security Audits|url = https://www.opentech.fund/article/nitrokey-storage-firmware-and-hardware-security-audits|website = Open Technology Fund|accessdate = 2016-01-15}}</ref> * Nitrokey's security is not dependent upon secret keys stored centrally with the device manufacturer. * Nitrokey is published as [[open source software]], [[free software]], and [[open hardware]].
== Devices == * Nitrokey Start <ref>{{Cite web|title = Nitrokey Start|url = https://shop.nitrokey.com/shop/product/nitrokey-start-6|website = Nitrokey Start Shop|accessdate = 2018-06-29}}</ref> * Nitrokey HSM <ref>{{Cite web|title = Nitrokey HSM|url = https://shop.nitrokey.com/shop/product/nitrokey-hsm-7|website = Nitrokey HSM Shop|accessdate = 2018-06-29}}</ref> * Nitrokey Pro <ref>{{Cite web|title = Nitrokey Pro|url = https://shop.nitrokey.com/shop/product/nitrokey-pro-3|website = Nitrokey Pro Shop|accessdate = 2018-06-29}}</ref> * Nitrokey Storage 16GB <ref>{{Cite web|title = Nitrokey Storage 16GB|url = https://shop.nitrokey.com/shop/product/nitrokey-storage-16gb-23|website = Nitrokey Storage 16GB Shop|accessdate = 2018-06-29}}</ref> * Nitrokey Storage 32GB <ref>{{Cite web|title = Nitrokey Storage 32GB|url = https://shop.nitrokey.com/shop/product/nitrokey-storage-32gb-12|website = Nitrokey Storage 32GB Shop|accessdate = 2018-06-29}}</ref> * Nitrokey Storage 64GB <ref>{{Cite web|title = Nitrokey Storage 64GB|url = https://shop.nitrokey.com/shop/product/nitrokey-storage-64gb-10|website = Nitrokey Storage 64GB Shop|accessdate = 2018-06-29}}</ref> * Nitrokey FIDO U2F <ref>{{Cite web|title = Nitrokey FIDO U2F|url = https://shop.nitrokey.com/shop/product/nitrokey-fido-u2f-20|website = Nitrokey FIDO U2F Shop|accessdate = 2018-06-29}}</ref>
== Philosophy == Nitrokey's developers believes that proprietary systems can't provide strong security and that security systems need to be open source. For instance there have been cases in which [[National Security Agency|NSA]] intercepts security devices being shipped and implanted backdoors into it. In 2011 [[RSA Security|RSA]] was hacked and secret keys of [[RSA SecurID|securID]] tokens been stolen which allowed hackers to circumvent their authentication.<ref>{{Cite web|title = RSA Break-In Leaves SecurID Users Sweating Bullets {{!}} Security {{!}} TechNewsWorld|url = http://www.technewsworld.com/story/72100.html|website = www.technewsworld.com|accessdate = 2016-01-07}}</ref> As revealed in 2010, many FIPS 140-2 Level 2 certified USB storage devices from various manufacturers could easily be cracked by using a default password.<ref>{{Cite web|title = FIPS 140-2 Level 2 Certified USB Memory Stick Cracked - Schneier on Security|url = https://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2010/01/fips_140-2_leve.html|website = www.schneier.com|accessdate = 2016-01-07}}</ref> Nitrokey, because of being open source and because of its transparency, wants to provide high secure system and avoid security issues which its proprietary rivals were facing. Nitrokey's mission is to provide the best Open Source security key to protect the digital lives of its users.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Using CryptoStick as an HSM|url = https://blog.mozilla.org/security/2013/02/13/using-cryptostick-as-an-hsm/|website = Mozilla Security Blog|accessdate = 2016-01-07}}</ref>

[[File:Optophone in detail.jpg|thumb|Detail view of the optophone]] The '''optophone''' is a device, used by the blind, that scans text and generates time-varying chords of tones to identify letters. It is one of the earliest known applications of [[sonification]]. Dr. [[Edmund Edward Fournier d'Albe|Edmund Fournier d'Albe]] of Birmingham University invented the optophone in 1913,<ref>{{cite journal|last=d'Albe|first=E. E. F.|title=On a Type-Reading Optophone|journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences|date=1 July 1914|volume=90|issue=619|pages=373–375|doi=10.1098/rspa.1914.0061}}</ref> which used [[selenium]] photosensors to detect black print and convert it into an audible output which could be interpreted by a blind person. [[Barr and Stroud]] participated in improving the resolution and usability of the instrument.<ref name = "Fournier1920">{{Citation | title = The Type-Reading Optophone | first = E. E. Fournier | last = d'Albe | journal = [[Scientific American]] | pages = 109–110 |date=October 1920 | url = http://statisfactions.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/12/opto1920.pdf}}</ref>
Only a few units were built and reading was initially exceedingly slow; a demonstration at the 1918 Exhibition involved Mary Jameson reading at one word per minute.<ref>{{Citation | title=The Optophone: Its Beginning and Development| author=Jameson, M.| journal=Bulletin of prosthetics research| pages=25–28| year=1966 | url=http://www.rehab.research.va.gov/jour/66/3/1/25.pdf }}</ref> Later models of the Optophone allowed speeds of up to 60 words per minute, though only some subjects are able to achieve this rate.<ref>{{Citation | title=An audio display for the blind| author=Fish, R.M.| journal=IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Engineering| issue=2| pages=144–154| year=1976| publisher=IEEE |doi=10.1109/tbme.1976.324576}}</ref>

{{No footnotes|date=April 2018}}
'''Outdoor–indoor transmission class''' (OITC) is a [[International standard|standard]] used for indicating the rate of transmission of sound between outdoor and indoor spaces in a structure. It is based on the [[ASTM International|ASTM]] E-1332 Standard Classification for the Determination of Outdoor–Indoor Transmission Class. An alternative similar standard for determining the rate of [[Sound proofing|acoustic isolation]] of a separation between spaces is [[sound transmission class]] (STC). While STC is based on a [[noise spectrum]] targeting speech sounds, OITC utilizes a source noise spectrum that considers [[Audio frequency|frequencies]] down to 80 Hz (aircraft/rail/truck traffic) and is weighted more to lower frequencies.

A '''radio science subsystem''' ('''RSS''') is a [[subsystem]] placed on board a [[spacecraft]] for [[radio science]] purposes.
==Function of the RSS==
The RSS uses [[radio signal]]s to probe a [[Interplanetary medium|medium]] such as a planetary [[atmosphere]]. The spacecraft transmits a highly stable signal to [[ground station]]s, receives such a signal from ground stations, or both. Since the transmitted signal [[parameter]]s are accurately known to the receiver, any changes to these parameters are attributable to the [[Radio propagation|propagation]] medium or to the relative motion of the spacecraft and ground station.
The RSS is usually not a separate instrument; its functions are usually "[[piggybacking (data transmission)|piggyback]]ed" on the existing [[telecommunication]]s subsystem. More advanced systems use multiple antennas with [[orthogonal]] [[Antenna (radio)#Polarization|polarization]]s.
==Radio science==
[[Radio]] science is commonly used to determine the [[gravity field]] of a [[moon]] or [[planet]] by observing [[Doppler shift]]. This requires a highly stable [[oscillator]] on the spacecraft, or more commonly a "2-way coherent" [[transponder]] that [[phase lock]]s the transmitted signal frequency to a rational multiple of a received [[uplink]] signal that usually also carries spacecraft commands.
Another common radio science observation is performed as a spacecraft is occulted by a planetary body. As the spacecraft moves behind the planet, its radio signals cuts through successively deeper layers of the planetary atmosphere. Measurements of [[signal strength]] and polarization vs time can yield data on the composition and temperature of the atmosphere at different altitudes.
It is also common to use multiple [[radio frequency|radio frequencies]] coherently derived from a common source to measure the dispersion of the propagation medium. This is especially useful in determining the free [[electron]] content of a planetary ionosphere.
==Spacecraft using RSS== * [[Cassini–Huygens]]<ref>[http://saturn.jpl.nasa.gov/spacecraft/instruments-cassini-rss.cfm Cassini-Huygens: Spacecraft-Instruments-Radio Science Subsystem (RSS)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080617050100/http://saturn.jpl.nasa.gov/spacecraft/instruments-cassini-rss.cfm |date=2008-06-17 }} Ulysess - European Space Agency</ref> * [[Mariner 2]], 4,5,6,7,9, and 10 * [[Voyager program|Voyager]] 1 and 2 * [[MESSENGER]]<ref>Srinivasan DK, Perry ME, Fielhauer KB, Smith DE and Zuber MT. ''The Radio Frequency Subsystem and Radio Science on the MESSENGER Mission''. 2007. Space Science Reviews 131 :557-571{{doi|10.1007/s11214-007-9270-7}}</ref> * [[Venus Express]]
==Functions== * Determine composition of [[gas cloud]]s such as atmospheres, [[solar corona]]s. * Characterize [[gravitational field]]s * Estimate masses of celestial [[satellite]]s that do not have satellites of their own. * To estimate particle size of [[Particle physics|particle field]]s * Estimate densities of [[ion field]]s.<ref>[http://ulysses.esa.int/science-e/www/object/index.cfm?fobjectid=34954&fbodylongid=1623 Instruments - RSS: Radio Science Subsystem] Cassini-Huygens, ESA</ref>
==Specifications==
* Given a [[deep space network]] (DSN) of receivers and/or transmitters. *A [[Ka-band]] [[traveling wave tube]] [[amplifier]] (K-TWTA) amplifies signals to a transmitting [[Antenna (radio)|antenna]] to be received by a distal [[radio telescope]]. *Ka-band translator (KAT) receives signal from a high gain antenna and retransmits the signal back to DSN. In this way the phase and phase-shift resulting from signal modification *Ka-band exciter (KEX) it supplies [[telemetry]] data. *S-band transmitter is used for radio science experiments. The transmitter receives signal from the RFS, amplifies and multiplies the signal, sending a 2290 MHz signal to the antenna. *Filter microwave emitter allow only [[microwave]]s of a given [[frequency]] to be emitted, there is a polarizing element. There are two-bypass filters and a wave-guide. The bypass filters allow different feed polarizations, receiving and transmitting.

{{Unreferenced|date=June 2007}} In [[electronics]], a '''signal trace''' on a [[printed circuit board]] (PCB) is the equivalent of a [[wire]] for [[electrical conduction|conducting]] [[signal (electrical engineering)|signal]]s. Each trace consists of a flat, narrow part of the [[copper]] foil that remains after etching. Signal traces are usually narrower than power or ground traces because the current carrying requirements are usually much less.

revision.text:
Empirically derived [[NDVI]] products have been shown to be unstable, varying with soil colour, soil moisture, and saturation effects from high density vegetation. In an attempt to improve NDVI, Huete <ref name="Huete1988">Huete, A.R., (1988) 'A soil-adjusted vegetation index (SAVI)' ''Remote Sensing of Environment'', vol. 25, issue 3, pp. 259-309. DOI: 10.1016/0034-4257(88)90106-X</ref> developed a vegetation index that accounted for the differential red and near-infrared extinction through the vegetation canopy. The index is a transformation technique that minimizes soil brightness influences from spectral vegetation indices involving red and near-infrared (NIR) wavelengths.
The index is given as:
:<math>\mbox{SAVI}=\frac{(\mbox{1}+\mbox{L})(\mbox{NIR}-\mbox{Red})}{(\mbox{NIR}+\mbox{Red}+\mbox{L})}</math>
where L is a canopy background adjustment factor. An L value of 0.5 in reflectance space was found to minimize soil brightness variations and eliminate the need for additional calibration for different soils. The transformation was found to nearly eliminate soil-induced variations in vegetation indices.<ref name = "Huete1988"/>

Pini Peter, owner of SpotOption said his company has left the binary options business and "I’m considering closing the company down altogether."{{cite news|last1=Appelberg|first1=Shelly|title=FBI Raids Tel Aviv Offices of Binary Options Platform Provider SpotOption|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/business/1.834878|accessdate=15 January 2018|publisher=Haaretz|date=14 January 2018}} On 30 January 2018 [[Facebook]] banned advertisements for binary options trading as well as well as for [[cryptocurrencies]] and [[initial coin offering]] (ICOs).{{cite news|last1=Frier|first1=Sarah|last2=Verhage|first2=Jules|title=Facebook Bans Ads Associated With Cryptocurrencies|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-01-30/facebook-bans-ads-associated-with-bitcoin-cryptocurrencies|accessdate=7 February 2018|publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=30 January 2018}}{{cite news|last1=Cornish|first1=Chloe|title=Facebook and regulators move to halt cryptocurrency scams|url=https://www.ft.com/content/9c1050ca-05f8-11e8-9650-9c0ad2d7c5b5|accessdate=7 February 2018|publisher=[[Financial Times]]|date=30 January 2018}} ==Founding== Sources disagree on the founding of the company. Bloomberg reports "Spot Option" at 7 Jabotinsky, [[Ramat Gan]], Israel, was founded in 2011;{{cite web | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/profiles/companies/1263307D:IT-spot-option-ltd | title=Bloomberg Private Company Profiles - Spot Option | accessdate=14 December 2016}} a location consistent with information from [[Companies House]] in the UK which list a founding date of 2016.{{cite web | url=https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/10132623/officers | publisher=Companies House (UK) | accessdate=14 December 2016 | title=Companies House entry for Spot Option UK }} The nonprofit [[public interest]] news organization ''[[Bureau of Investigative Journalism]]'' reports a unit in Israel appearing in 2010.{{cite news | author=Newman, Melanie | publisher=The Bureau of Investigative Journalism | title=80% losses guaranteed! Inside the murky world of binary options trading | url=http://labs.thebureauinvestigates.com/binary-options-real-risks-investigation/ | date=14 December 2016 | accessdate=14 December 2016 }} They also report that the founder and primary shareholder is Pinchas Peterktzishvilly, also known as Pini Peter, who was convicted on [[money laundering]] charges in 2005.{{cite news|last1=Newman|first1=Melanie|last2=Jones|first2=Meirion|last3=Fielding-Smith|first3=Abigail|last4=Mathiason|first4=Nick|title=Revealed: How Brits are losing millions to UK’s biggest scam while the government stands by|url=https://www.thebureauinvestigates.com/2016/09/20/revealed-brits-losing-millions-uks-biggest-scam-government-stands/|accessdate=15 February 2017|publisher=[[Bureau for Investigative Journalism]]|date=20 September 2016}} According to an advertisement for [[Banc De Binary]], its CEO Oren Shabat Laurent was a founder of SpotOption.{{cite web|title=Banc de Binary First CySEC Regulated Binary Options Broker|url=http://binaryoptionsnow.com/2013/01/banc-de-binary-now-the-first-officially-regulated-binary-options-broker/|website=Binary Options|accessdate=12 January 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170112023932/http://binaryoptionsnow.com/2013/01/banc-de-binary-now-the-first-officially-regulated-binary-options-broker/|archivedate=12 January 2017|date=8 January 2013}} Oren himself was embroiled in significant controversy surrounding hiring experts to obfuscate the truth about Banc de Binary and SpotOption's affiliate funnel online{{Cite news|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/wikipedia-vs-banc-de-binary-a-3-year-battle-against-binary-options-fake-news/|title=Wikipedia vs. Banc De Binary: A 3-year battle against binary options ‘fake news’|work=The Times of Israel|access-date=2017-08-29|language=en-US}}; which effectively sees the latter create a range of affiliate funnel online products such as auto-traders, which in turn lure new depositors into placing funds at Spot Option's tied agents and brands. ==Market positioning and controversy== The firm claims that two thirds of the binary option dealers around the world use SpotOption, and that the firm has $5 billion annual trading volume. In 2015, the company's former CEO, Ran Amiran, said "SpotOption is the industry". SpotOption and TechFinancials together supply trading technology to brokers with claimed $8 billion annual turnover.{{citation|publisher=Reuters|title=Mind the Gap: From Israel via London, an online gambling scam traps thousands|authors=Tova Cohen and Luke Baker|date=27 September 2016|url=https://www.reuters.com/investigates/special-report/israel-investing-binary/}} SpotOption supplied brokerages including the now defunct Banc De Binary, formerly SpotOption's biggest client, and smaller brokerages including [[itrader]],{{Cite web|first=Andrew |last=Saks-McLeod |title=iTrader saga continues |date=20 November 2016 |publisher=Finance Feeds |url=http://financefeeds.com/itrader-call-centers-still-operating-despite-regulatory-raid-arrest-key-staff-executives-pretend-jpmorgan/ options|url=https://www.ft.com/content/5621b608-e24f-11e6-9645-c9357a75844a|accessdate=2 February 2017|publisher=Financial Times|date=2 February 2017}}{{cite web|title=Binary trading group winds down after regulatory issues|url=https://www.ft.com/content/7b4c13b2-d7fd-11e6-944b-e7eb37a6aa8e |website=[[Financial Times]]|accessdate=12 January 2017|date=12 January 2017}} * BD Swiss, also known as news|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/fleeced-by-israeli-binary-options-firm-canadian-man-commits-suicide/|title=Fleeced by Israeli binary options firm, Canadian man dies by suicide|work=The Times of Israel|access-date=2017-08-29|language=en-US}} According to the ''Bureau of Investigative Journalism'', "PowerPoint presentations posted online by Hong Kong-based SpotOption sales manager Thomas Chang in 2016 and former Middle East sales manager Fakhri Husseini in 2013 told potential brokers that only 20% of people who invest in binary options ever get any money back after signing up." SpotOption exhibited at the IFX Expo International held in Cyprus in May 2016. Their director of marketing, Tammy Levy, when asked about crackdowns by law enforcement, was quoted as saying "SpotOption is a technology company, okay? Everyone is responsible for checking regulation in the jurisdiction where they want to work. I am here to tell you what options you have technologically."{{cite news | url = http://www.timesofisrael.com/as-victims-pile-up-the-binary-options-industry-parties-in-cyprus/ | title=As victims pile up, the binary option industry parties in Cyprus | newspaper=Times of Israel | author=Stuart, Hunter | date=15 June 2016}} ==Gambling using binary options== At the 2011 [[IGaming Business|iGaming Super Show]], the company showed its platform to traditional gaming vendors, claiming it was compatible with industry regulations and profitable for operators. Peterktzishvilly (Pini Peter) said they intended "to bridge the forex and gaming industries".{{citation|via=[[HighBeam]] {{subscription required}}|title=SpotOption Presents at iGaming Super Show in Dublin|work=Entertainment Close-Up|date=10 June 2011|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-258771117.html}}{{citation|via=[[HighBeam]] {{subscription required}}|title=SpotOption Displays Binary Options Platform at iGaming Super Show, Dublin|work=Entertainment Close-Up|date=11 June 2011|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-258771274.html}} The company appeared at numerous gambling industry trade shows including ICE Totally Gaming in London in 2014{{citation|publisher=ICE Totally Gaming|title=ICE 2014 list of exhibitors|p=12|url=https://issuu.com/gbmediacorp/docs/ice-digital-2014}} and the [[American Gaming Association]]'s [[Global Gaming Expo|Global Gaming Expo Asia]] 2015 in Macao, calling itself creator of "the perfect financial game".{{Cite web |work=2015 Exhibitor List |title=SpotOption |publisher=[[American Gaming Association]] and Reed Exhibition for [[Global Gaming Expo|Global Gaming Expo Asia]] |url=http://www.g2easia.com/en/Exhibitors/275426/SpotOption |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6oK2oC8NE?url=http://www.g2easia.com/en/Exhibitors/275426/SpotOption |archive-date=16 February 2017 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }} In May 2015, SpotOption launched its new Spot5 platform that would include new instruments called "digital contracts".{{Cite news|url=https://fxaxe.com/news/spotoption-launches-new-product/|title=SpotOption Launches New Product - FXaxe|date=2017-05-27|work=FXaxe|access-date=2017-05-27|language=en-US}} These were developed in order to meet new regulatory requirements. On 23 August 2017, the company announced their intention to launch a blockchain based trading platform for binary options called SpotChain, a new product which will raise money from the crowds to fund their operations.{{Cite news|url=https://www.financemagnates.com/fintech/news/exclusive-spotoption-announces-blockchain-based-trading-via-spotchain/|title=Exclusive: SpotOption Announces Blockchain-Based Trading via SpotChain {{!}} Finance Magnates|date=2017-08-23|work=Finance Magnates {{!}} Financial and business news|access-date=2017-08-29|language=en-US}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== {{cite news|title=FBI arrests Israeli binary options CEO as she disembarks El Al flight at JFK|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/fbi-arrests-israeli-binary-options-ceo-as-she-disembarks-el-al-flight-at-jfk/|accessdate=25 September 2017|publisher=Times of Israel|date=24 September 2017}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.spotoption.com/}} [[Category:Options traders]] [[Category:Companies established in 2009]] [[Category:Technology companies]]

[[File:Students using SMILE in Ghana.jpg|thumb|Students using the Stanford Mobile Inquiry-based Learning Environment in Ghana]]
'''Stanford Mobile Inquiry-based Learning Environment (SMILE)''' [https://smile.stanford.edu https://smile.stanford.edu] is a mobile learning management server software designed to help students study school subject matter, develop higher order learning skills and generate transparent real-time learning analytics.<ref name="gseit-smile">{{cite web|url=https://gse-it.stanford.edu/research/project/smile|title=Project Overview, Stanford Mobile Inquiry-based Learning Environment|accessdate=27 September 2016|website=Office of Innovation & Technology, Stanford GSE}}</ref>
SMILE combines a mobile-based question application for students with a management application for teachers. The technology allows students to create multiple-choice questions on mobile phones during class and share these questions with their classmates and teacher.<ref name="bucknerkim">{{cite journal|doi=10.1007/s11125-013-9269-7|title=Integrating technology and pedagogy for inquiry-based learning: The Stanford Mobile Inquiry-based Learning Environment (SMILE)|last1=Buckner|first1=Elizabeth|last2=Kim|first2=Paul}}</ref>
The main goal of SMILE is to develop students’ questioning skills, encourage greater student-centric activities and practices in classrooms,<ref name="bucknerkim" /> and enable a low-cost mobile wireless learning environment.<ref name="otl-smile">{{cite web|url=http://techfinder.stanford.edu/technology_detail.php?ID=31042|title=Stanford Mobile Inquiry-based Learning Environment (SMILE) - PATENT|website=Stanford University Office of Technology Licensing|accessdate=27 September 2016}}</ref>
==History==
Seeds of Empowerment (Seeds), is a global non-profit 501(c)(3) organization founded in 2009 by [[Paul_Kim_(academic)|Dr. Paul Kim]]. The NGO helped develop SMILE and also pilot studies around the world using the software since 2009.<ref name="seeds">{{cite web|url=http://seedsofempowerment.org/about-us/vision/|title=Our Vision|website=Seeds of Empowerment|accessdate=27 September 2016}}</ref>
A major contribution to the initial technical design of SMILE was originated from a research study led by [[Paul_Kim_(academic)|Dr. Paul Kim]] along with his research assistants at Stanford University. The initial research study named [http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/6137845/?reload=true PSILAN] (PocketSchool Interactive Learning Network) investigated a portable ad-hoc network solution that can enable a multi-user interactive learning environment in areas where resources such as electricity or access to Internet is limited. This research was part of multiple projects affiliated with Stanford's major interdisciplinary research program named [http://pomi.stanford.edu/ Programmable Open Mobile Internet] backed by [https://www.nsf.gov/ National Science Foundation].
The latest developments on SMILE have been made by [https://gse-it.stanford.edu/ GSE-IT] at the Graduate School of Education of Stanford University and partnering organizations such as [http://www.edify.org/ Edify.org]. The license of the trademarks, software, hardware, and its technical design remains with the [http://techfinder.stanford.edu/technology_detail.php?ID=31042 Office of Technology Licensing] (OTL) at Stanford University.
Recently, SMILE has been listed as one of innovative tools for the schools of tomorrow by [http://educationcommission.org/ United Nations's Education Commission], chaired by [[Gordon Brown]], former Prime Minister of United Kingdom, in its 2016 report named "[http://report.educationcommission.org/report/ Learning Generation Report]"
==How it works== [[File:A sample question developed using SMILE.jpg|thumb|A sample question developed using SMILE]]
The software allows students to generate, share, and evaluate multimedia-rich questions.<ref name="bucknerkim" /> The data management software gathers these responses and the time students take to respond, and saves them for the teacher to analyze. Teachers can also enter questions to test information.<ref name="bucknerkim" />
Finally, the software also allows for both teamwork and competition which teachers can use to promote a classroom environment that is either collaborative or competitive, depending on what will motivate students.<ref name="bucknerkim" />
===Operating modes=== SMILE has five operating modes. The facilitator chooses the mode for each activity.
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Mode ! Description |- | Exam Mode | Teachers post questions for students to solve, evaluate, and comment while the system presents the student performance outcome results in real-time |- | Brainstorming Mode | Participants discuss, evaluate, rank, and comment open-ended questions |- | Open-to-close-End-Mode | Participants generate, discuss, evaluate, comment, and rank open-ended questions and turn the selected open-ended questions into multiple-choice questions. |- | Student-Paced Mode | Students generate, solve, evaluate, and discuss questions in an asynchronous manner so participants can typically participate in sessions without any time-constraint |- | Organizer-Paced Mode | Organizers control different stages of sessions with specific time limits in each stage (i.e., generating, solving, evaluating, and reviewing questions).<ref name="gseit-smile" /> |}
===Question ratings=== The instrument is designed to identify performance variations. It enables organizers to define five different levels of question quality. For example:<ref name="gseit-smile" />
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Question Difficulty ! Description |- | Category 1 | Students respond with minimum cognition involving simple recalls or simple arithmetic calculations |- | Category 2 | Students conduct a simple analysis on question types and qualities (e.g., asking questions about questions) or solve problems with simple reasoning. These questions are designed to assess if students can recognize and make distinctions between low quality questions and higher order thinking questions. |- | Category 3 | Students solve given problems with an intermediate level of cognition and analysis. |- | Category 4 | Students solve given problems with a deeper level of analysis and reasoning. |- | Category 5 | Students ignore distracting information and extract only accurate information to make a necessary inference. Students must formulate their own rational equation to arrive at a conclusion. |}
In lieu of test scores, the ratings of the questions can be used to assess learning outcomes.<ref>{{cite web|title=SMILE (Stanford Mobile Inquiry-based Learning Environment) - Paul Kim|url=http://www.unesco.org/archives/multimedia/?s=films_details&pg=33&id=2958|website=UNESCO|accessdate=19 October 2016}}</ref> Analyzing a student's ability to rate other student's questions can be used to determine the student's level of critical thinking skills. The process of rating questions from their peers allows the students to think about the content in a deeper way.<ref>{{cite web|title=How to Help Mobile Education Go Global|url=http://ww2.kqed.org/mindshift/2013/02/28/how-to-help-mobile-education-go-global/|website=KQED MindShift|accessdate=19 October 2016}}</ref>
==Praxis== SMILE is intended for a wide range of educational settings. Not only is SMILE is content-agnostic, the pedagogical model behind SMILE is to encourage the student to make critical inquiries--the hard work, the investigation--instead of being told the answers by an educator. Many successful implementations of SMILE are implemented by teachers incorporating SMILE two to three times a week. <ref>{{cite web|title=SMILE, Your Kid is Learning|url=http://www.ewa.org/blog-educated-reporter/smile-your-kid-learning|website=Education Writers Association|accessdate=19 October 2016}}</ref> To address the rapidly advancing technological age, SMILE effectively allows schools and teachers to flip the classroom.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dr. Paul Kim: "It's time to flip the classroom"|url=http://www.wise-qatar.org/paul-kim-flipped-classrooms-stanford|website=wise ed review, Qatar Foundation}}</ref>
===SMILE in Elementary Classrooms=== SMILE can be used by students in an elementary classroom. Students create questions which are then solved and rated by peers. The entire process is controlled and monitored by a teacher with an activity management application. <ref name="seol-sharp-kim">{{cite journal|last1=Seol|first1=Sunmi|last2=Sharp|first2=Aaron|last3=Kim|first3=Paul|title=Stanford Mobile Inquiry-based Learning Environment (SMILE): using mobile phones to promote student inquires in the elementary classroom|journal=Proceedings of the 2011 International conference on frontiers in education: Computer science & computer engineering|date=2011|pages=270-276|url=https://gse-it.stanford.edu/sites/default/files/worldcomp11_SMILE.pdf}}</ref>
In the learning process, students proceed through stages of '''Make Your Question''', where students create multiple choice questions. '''Solve Questions''' aggregates the questions and sends them back to students to solve and rate on a five-point scale. '''See Results''' allows students to see the their score. <ref name="seol-sharp-kim" />
The teacher has multiple features at his or her disposal. The '''Activity Flow''' window allows the teacher to activate the various stages of the activity. The '''Student Status''' window displays the current status of each student. The '''Scoreboard''' displays individual student’s responses. The '''Question Status''' window displays metadata about the question. The '''Question''' window displays the question itself and its predetermined correct answer. The '''Top Scorers''' window displays which student achieved the highest score and which question received the highest ratings. The '''Save Questions''' button allows the teacher to save the data from a given exercise to the server.<ref name="seol-sharp-kim" />
===SMILE in Math Classrooms=== SMILE takes advantage of mobile devices to increase participation, engagement, and collaboration from the students. Students are creating their own math questions, including using the device's camera to take pictures of their questions. All participants have access to the questions during and after class. <ref name="song-kim-karimi">{{cite journal|last1=Song|first1=Donggil|last2=Kim|first2=Paul|last3=Karimi|first3=Arafeh|title=Inquiry-based Learning Environment Using Mobile Devices in Math Classroom|journal=Proceedings of the Association for Education Communications and Technology, 2012. Kentucky|date=2012|pages=386-392|url=http://www.aect.org/pdf/proceedings12/2012i/12_20.pdf}}</ref>
In a typical SMILE activity, students go through several phases of learning. They are: Introduction and device exploration, Prompt for problems, Student grouping and generating questions, Question generation, Question solving, Result review, Reflection, and Repetition and enrichment. Song, Kim, and Karimi describe this in their 2012 paper, Inquiry-based Learning Environment Using Mobile Devices in Math Classroom. <ref name="song-kim-karimi" />
===SMILE in Participatory Action Research=== SMILE can be used in participatory action research to engage participants in critical thinking and community engagement while eventually deriving solutions that are locally relevant. <ref name="kim-an">{{cite journal|last1=Kim|first1=Paul|last2=An|first2=Ji-Young|title=New Evaluation Vector through the Stanford Mobile Inquiry-Based Learning Environment (SMILE) for Participatory Action Research|journal=Healthcare Informatics Research|date=2016|volume=22|issue=3|pages=164-171|url=http://synapse.koreamed.org/DOIx.php?id=10.4258/hir.2016.22.3.164}}</ref>
During the question generation process, participants can capture images from textbooks or take photos of environmental issues to address. Once the questions are generated, they are aggregated and redistributed to the participants. The participants then go through a period of reflection, response, evaluation, and verification. <ref name="kim-an"/>
The process enables the participants to think beyond simple health-relevant facts. Also, SMILE leverages the collective construction of inquiries, leading to more reliable and accurate depiction of the reality as a whole. They are able to distinguish facts from opinions, verify sources, analyze cause and effect, determine faulty generalizations, and avoid oversimplification. <ref name="kim-an"/>
By empowering the participants to co-evaluate and reflect their own phenomena, the external researcher's role is simply to facilitate conversation.<ref name="kim-an"/> Examining the questions and answer choices generated by participants help researchers uncover important insights. <ref name="kim-an"/>
==Technology== [[File:SMILE Plug (Marvell).jpg|thumb|SMILE Plug on Marvell hardware]] '''SMILE Plug''' creates an ad-hoc network which enables students to engage in SMILE activities and exchange inquiries with peers in their classrooms or their own school.<ref name="bucknerkim" /> Participants in the SMILE Plug model must be physically present and connected to the ad-hoc SMILE WiFi network. A SMILE Plug router contains the SMILE server software, KIWIX, Khan Academy Lite, various open education resources including open education textbooks, and four different coding language school programs.<ref name="gseit-smile" />
'''SMILE Global''' enables students around the world to exchange their inquiries regardless of their location.<ref name="bucknerkim" /> People who are interested in a particular topic (e.g., for example, 'health'), they can search the keyword and also create their own questions, respond to existing questions, or comment on questions and answer.<ref name="kim-an" /> The SMILE Global server is accessible in the cloud.<ref name="gseit-smile" />
Both SMILE Plug and SMILE Global allow students to incorporate multimedia components in their questions: SMILE Plug uses images, and SMILE Global uses images, audio and video.<ref name="bucknerkim" />
===Cost=== The cost of implementing a SMILE activity depends on the infrastructure available in the school, but at minimum costs: $80 per mobile phone (one for every 2-3 students), $300 for a notebook laptop computer, and $100 for a local router.<ref name="bucknerkim" />
Because of the ubiquitous nature of mobile devices, the low barrier to entry, and the modular growth potential, mobile devices provide a low-cost, high-reward alternative to the traditional computer lab model.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dr. Paul Kim: “Es hora de voltear el aula”|url=https://innovacioneducativa.fundaciontelefonica.com/blog/2015/07/22/dr-paul-kim-es-hora-de-voltear-el-aula/|website=Fundación Telefónica|accessdate=19 October 2016}}</ref>
In many cases, business leaders provided local telecom network infrastructure and equipment such as mobile devices and computers, while local educational administrators facilitated the participation of local schools and offered teacher workshops. University staff conducted research on strategies to enhance the model within the local context and NGO partners provided localized knowledge, program oversight, and project coordination. This approach brings together many stakeholders, without exhausting the limited resources of any one sector.<ref name="bucknerkim" />
In 2012, the SMILE team partnered with Marvell to create SMILE Consortium.<ref>{{cite web|title=Marvell and Stanford create SMILE Plug cloud computer, SMILE Consortium to get companies and devs to build a better education system|url=https://www.engadget.com/2012/09/18/marvell-stanford-smile-plug-smile-consortiumcloud-computer-smile-con/|accessdate=16 October 2016|website=engadget}}</ref>
===SMILE Plug on Raspberry Pi=== [[File:SMILE Plug (Pi + LED).jpg|thumb|SMILE Plug on Raspberry Pi]] In 2016, the SMILE Plug was implemented on a Raspberry Pi 3. SMILE will boot in one minute when plugged into USB power. In developing countries with limited access to electricity, a USB battery pack is required. The Pi, designed for use in areas of low internet connectivity, provides a local WiFi access point. Students and teachers with mobile devices, tablets, laptops, and computers can connect to the Plug.
The Plug requires a microSD card which acts as the hard drive and local repository of the offline resources. In order to update the SMILE Plug, one will swap out the previous microSD card with a newer microSD card with updated resources.
The total cost of a SMILE Plug varies depending on the material parts used to build the device. The base price is $85, including $35 for the Raspberry Pi motherboard; $10 for a case; $40 for a 128GB Class 10 microSD card. A battery pack for 12 hours of use costs an additional $25; the LED screen an additional $40.
===SMILE Global and Natural Language Processing=== In 2017, SMILE Global will interface with a natural language processing API. The SMILE team has prepared a databank of questions pre-categorized according to the question quality rubric. The API will return a rating for each question that is submitted on SMILE Global. The immediate response and feedback will give students a chance to make improvements to their questions in real time.
The question quality rubric will allow teachers to gauge the level of learning from their students. <ref>{{cite web |last1=Vander Ark |first1=Tom |title=Stanford CTO Provokes Good Questions Online (And Off) |url=http://www.gettingsmart.com/2016/12/stanford-cto-provokes-good-questions-online-and-off/ |website=Getting Smart Podcast |accessdate=4 June 2018 |ref=gettingsmart}}</ref>
==Projects== SMILE has reached over 25 countries, including North America, India, Argentina, Mexico, Costa Rica, Colombia, Nepal, China, Uruguay, Indonesia, South Korea, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, and Tanzania.<ref name="bucknerkim" />
===Argentina=== Students used SMILE to think critically about what it means to be an engaged citizen in their community, generating questions for their peers about such potential moral dilemmas as homelessness, suicide, stealing, and school bullying and violence. One student addressed the increasing incidence of suicide locally and asked their peers for the major cause. This revealed additional benefits of SMILE—not only is it a tool for managing student learning and assessment, it also facilitates discussions of issues that students see as important.<ref name="bucknerkim" />
In 2012, the Ministry of Education in Buenos Aires looked into modifying the cell phone prohibition use in the classroom, in effect since 2006. In addition to using SMILE, educators can now create executable programs on mobile devices to help facilitate learning in the classroom. <ref>{{cite web|title=El celular se usa cada vez más en clase para estudiar|url=http://www.clarin.com/educacion/celular-usa-vez-clase-estudiar_0_712728817.html|website=Clarin Propietario Arte Gráfico Editorial Argentino S.A|accessdate=19 October 2016}}</ref>
SMILE workshops on Music, Language Arts, and Mathematics was implemented in Misiones and Talarin August 2011. By using an exploratory learning pedagogy, students were able to compose songs. The power of mobile devices to reach the last mile and the last school is most evident where electricity and internet access is not guaranteed. <ref>{{cite web|title=Los teléfonos móviles son una herramienta increíble|url=http://www.infotechnology.com/historico/Los-telefonos-moviles-son-una-herramienta-increible-20110808-0003.html|website=Infotechnology.com|accessdate=19 October 2016}}</ref>
In rural settings, desktop computers may be too cumbersome and have too high of an overhead. Mobile phones and tablets, on the other hand, are portable and battery-powered, making for a flexible mobile-learning environment. One of the keys in deploying mobile technology is a focus on bringing the desired content with a strong pedagogical foundation. <ref>{{cite web|title=Los smartphones van al colegio|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1416314-los-smartphones-van-al-colegio|website=LA NACION|accessdate=19 October 2016}}</ref>
===Chile=== Due to the centralized nature of Chile, it is harder for education to reach the poorest areas of the country. The concept of a mobile classroom, or "pocket school," connected and tied together by a network of mobile phones, is an attempt to take advantage of the resources already available in the most underserved communities. <ref>{{cite web|title=Allô, la "smart classe" ?|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/a-la-une/article/2012/11/13/allo-la-smart-classe_1789623_3208.html|website=Le Monde|accessdate=19 October 2016}}</ref>
===Indonesia=== Students were asked to generate math questions covering a wide range of topics, from triangle angle sum theorem, to fractions, areas and diameters. Teachers were surprised at the students’ enthusiasm. They were also surprised at the students’ ability to adopt the technology by themselves and to train each other and even their teachers.<ref name="bucknerkim" />
===South Korea=== SMILE Global was tested with medical students at Chungbuk National University. Criteria for high-quality questions, criteria rubrics, and examples of high- and low-quality questions were discussed with students first. This initial overview seemed to be important in promoting deep inquiry. As the students were already very experienced in using technology, they spent 60% of their time on the inquiry-making task.<ref name="bucknerkim" />
==Findings== {{Quote box |quote = The pre-service teachers reported that SMILE makes student thinking visible. Younger students are better at creating higher quality questions. Older students are already used to the traditional learning model where fact-recall is the major theme of classroom activities. |source = ''Quote from "Preservice teachers’ uses of SMILE to enact studentgenerated questioning practices" <ref name="hsu-kim">{{cite journal|last1=Hsu|first1=Hui-Yin|last2=Kim|first2=Paul|title=Preservice Teachers’ Uses of SMILE to Enact Student-Generated Questioning Practices.|journal=E-Learn: World Conference on E-Learning in Corporate, Government, Healthcare, and Higher Education|volume=2015|issue=1|url=https://www.learntechlib.org/p/152032/proceedings_152032.pdf}}</ref> }}
Studies suggest that SMILE could be implemented relatively easily in a wide range of classroom settings; it was adopted by students relatively quickly; and it increased the use of inquiry-based pedagogies.<ref name="bucknerkim" />
As students evaluated each other’s questions and understood which ones got higher ratings, over time they developed questions that were more conceptually difficult and of higher quality.<ref name="bucknerkim" />
Teachers need an initial training period and some follow-up mentoring so they can facilitate questions.<ref name="bucknerkim" /> Tailoring the content of the trainings to the local environment is crucial. Without putting the benefits of SMILE into the local context, teachers and students will find no compelling reason to adopt the pedagogy. <ref>{{cite web|title=SMILE - Stanford Mobile Inquiry-based Learning Environment|website=Swiss Contribution|url=http://ukexport.danmar-computers.com.pl/en/item/34-smile-stanford-mobile-inquiry-based-learning-environment|accessdate=19 October 2016}}</ref>
Finally, local education officials must be on board. SMILE worked best when officials, along with civil society organizations, universities, and local businesses, worked together to bring it to classrooms and supported different elements of its implementation.<ref name="bucknerkim" />
===Cohesiveness of Integration=== {{Quote box |quote = The most important lesson here is that the process of developing critical thinking skills is probably not too different from the process of language acquisition: It takes time and good guidance along with ample exposure. |source = ''Quote from "Using Technology to Teach the Art of Asking Questions" <ref name="mcgivney-kim">{{cite web|last1=McGivney|first1=Eileen|last2=Kim|first2=Paul|title=Using Technology to Teach the Art of Asking Questions|url=https://ssir.org/articles/entry/using_technology_to_teach_the_art_of_asking_questions|website=Stanford Social Innovation Review|accessdate=14 December 2016}}</ref> }} The success rate of implementing SMILE is dependent on how cohesively inquiry-based pedagogy is tied to the curricula taught at a school. While SMILE can be implemented with the existing curricula (for example, with students asking simple recall math questions), it is most effective as an additional platform to foster critical thinking. This could come in the form of a regularly scheduled SMILE class each week to discuss questioning. Although many students shy away at first, repeated practice learning how to answer, rate, and create questions within a comfortable space will allow them to grow their higher-order thinking skills.<ref name="mcgivney-kim" />
Higher teacher motivation, better classroom integration, and higher frequency of use are three factors that increase SMILE retention. Teachers are encouraged to help students become knowledge-holders and questioners; teachers themselves are encouraged to challenge the status quo of rote memorization inside the classroom. Though question-and-answer sessions may create uncomfortable situations where the teachers sole authority is questioned, the additional transfer of knowledge and learning happens in this discomfort and is beneficial to the student's growth.<ref name="mcgivney-kim" />
===Student Engagement=== For online classrooms, SMILE helps drive student engagement with the content, the community, and the instructor. A study on pre-service teachers meeting remotely showed positive correlation in using SMILE and achieving higher levels of collaboration, higher sense of autonomy, and optimizing content relevance and authenticity.<ref name="park-kim">{{cite journal|last1=Park|first1=Elizabeth|last2=Kim|first2=Paul|title=A Case Study Exploring Student Engagement with Stanford Mobile Inquiry-based Learning Environment (SMILE)|journal=GLOKALde|date=October 2016|volume=2|issue=Number: 4, Article 5|url=https://www.glokalde.com/pdf/issues/8/Article5.pdf }}</ref>
Relationships between students and teachers changed during the SMILE workshops. Teachers were not simply transmitting information to students; rather, students were drawing on written or digital resources to formulate their own questions. The teachers played important roles in guiding students through the solutions to difficult questions, correcting any mistakes, and elaborating on student-generated questions.<ref name="bucknerkim" />
===Challenges=== School and country contexts highly influence students’ initial abilities to form deep questions. In the developing world, many teachers lack adequate teacher training. Their training is often limited to content, rather than pedagogical practices. In some cases, when teachers were asked to use new technology before they were comfortable with it, their discomfort led them to stifle students’ questions. Cultural norms governing relations between adults and students, and socialization into situational authority roles, may also inhibit student questioning.<ref name="bucknerkim" />
SMILE was more difficult to implement in areas where rote memorization pedagogies were typical. Some students found it hard to generate their own questions, given their previous classroom experiences with rote memorization activities.<ref name="bucknerkim" />
Additionally, students with little experience manipulating smart phones took longer to understand and use the technology, but eventually adjusted after exploration.<ref name="bucknerkim" />

{{Infobox company | name = Swedish Bar Systems | type = Public | foundation = 2005 | location = [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]] | industry = [[Inventory control system]] [[Hospitality]] Systems, [[Computer hardware]] | homepage = [http://www.swedishbarsystems.com www.swedishbarsystems.com] }}
'''Swedish Bar Systems''' is a [[Stockholm]] based supplier and distributor of a bar inventory management system specializing in [[liquor]] [[logistics]] in the [[hospitality]] industry. The system comprises hardware, software and services which is used to improve business strategies and processes. The information collected is used for research and business development and also synchronized with the establishments [[accounting]] and [[inventory]] processes to increase time management and revenue. Swedish Bar Systems currently has installations throughout [[Scandinavia]].
==History== Founded in 2005 in Stockholm, Sweden, the company released the first bar inventory management system to use free pour spouts, able to measure the volume of liquor poured and wirelessly transfer the encoded information to a database. The pourers contain a flow [[sensor]] that measure the volume dispensed in real time, which provides an overview of the establishment inventory.
==The System== Swedish Bar Systems manufactures and sells hardware, software and services for the liquor market. The systems hardware and software is used in the hospitality industry, which includes [[touch screen]] computers for showing and monitoring logistics. The spout measures free poured volumes and sends this information wirelessly to a receiver. The receiver collects all signals from the spouts and enters it into the database that handles the inventory.
Swedish Bar Systems provides numerous solutions for different establishments sizes, including single-entity, [[chains]], [[Chain store|franchises]] or multiple locations, including [[casino]]s, [[stadiums]], and [[cruise ships]]. Swedish Bar Systems have the ability to interface with other [[Point of sale|POS]] systems such as [[Squirrel Systems]] and [[MICROS Systems]]. To connect bars or locations into one database a local server is set up, so the information can be shown on software modules.
==Acquisitions== Swedish Bar Systems received several million [[Swedish krona|SEK]] investments in 2006, 2007 and later 2008 they were purchased by the listed company DQE Designed Quality Entertainment on the Nordic MTF list, a [[subsidiary]] to Börse Stuttgart.<ref name="sbsacquisition">{{cite press release |title = Swedish Bar Systems Acquisition |publisher = Swedish Bar Systems |date = 2009-01-22 |url = http://swedishbarsystems.com/images/Bokslutkommunikereport.pdf|accessdate=2009-01-23}}</ref>
==Awards== The company has been recognized by the [[Financial Times]],<ref name="FT">{{cite press release | title = Financial Times Award | publisher = KTH University | date = 2006-05-24 | url = http://www.sses.se/SSESTemplates/page.aspx?id=524 | accessdate=2009-01-23}}</ref> and awarded several national and international awards for their concept, among others [[McKinsey & Company]] - [[Venture Cup]],<ref name="McKinsey & Company – Venture Cup">{{cite press release |title = McKinsey & Company – Venture Cup Award |publisher = KTH University |date = 2006-05-24 |url = http://www.csc.kth.se/aktuellt/notiser/venture/index.php |accessdate=2009-01-23}}</ref> [[London school of Economics]],<ref name="LSE">{{cite press release |title = London School of Economics - EPOCH award |publisher = SSES |date = 2006-03-02 |url = http://www.sses.se/SSESTemplates/page.aspx?id=457 |accessdate=2009-01-23}}</ref> [[RMIT University|Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology]] <ref name="RMIT">{{cite press release |title = RMIT Award |publisher =RMIT University |date = 2006-11-14 |url = http://www.rmit.edu.au/browse/News%20and%20Events%2FNews%2FAchievements%2FBusiness%2F;ID=agdpgg6ymv58z;STATUS=A |accessdate=2009-01-23}}</ref> and [[Stockholm School of Entrepreneurship]] (SSES) <ref name="SSES">{{cite press release |title = Stockholm School of Entrepreneurship Award |publisher = SSES |date = 2005-06-01 |url = http://www.sses.se/SSESTemplates/Page.aspx?id=461 |accessdate=2009-01-23}}</ref> innovation award.
